questions.clue: In 1936, this African American athlete won four gold medals at the Berlin Olympics, challenging Nazi ideology.
This iconic image from the 1968 Mexico City Games showed Tommie Smith and John Carlos raising this symbol during the medal ceremony.
In 1972, Olga Korbut gained fame for her performance in gymnastics representing this country.
This swimmer broke Mark Spitz's 36-year-old record by winning 8 gold medals at the 2008 Olympics.
Dubbed the 'Miracle on Ice,' the USA hockey team's victory at the 1980 Winter Olympics was against this country's team.
This big-footed creature has been a legend in the Pacific Northwest, sharing a name with a popular Portland basketball team.
In Scotland, this aquatic monster is rumored to inhabit Loch Ness and shares a nickname with the college sports team University of Vermont.
Known for its large wingspan, this moth-like creature reportedly caused panic in West Virginia and lends its name to a minor league baseball team.
This New Jersey legend is often described as having a kangaroo-like body and bat wings and shares part of its name with an NHL hockey team.
Reportedly sighted in Point Pleasant, this cryptid is believed to have connections to a local bridge collapse and shares its name with a 2001 film and a minor league hockey team.
This trumpeter, nicknamed 'Satchmo', is famous for songs like 'What a Wonderful World'.
Known for his 'Blue Train' album, this saxophonist was a major influence in jazz music.
Just like Michael Jordan, this jazz pianist was considered the greatest, especially known for 'Take Five'.
Sharing part of his name with a famous baseball player's nickname, this bandleader popularized swing in the 1930s.
This jazz trumpeter, who also enjoyed boxing, was a pioneer of the bebop genre along with Charlie Parker.
This ancient Roman amphitheater, famous for gladiator contests, could seat up to 50,000 spectators.
Designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, this Pennsylvania house is famous for its cantilevered structure over a waterfall.
This domed sports stadium, known for being used during Hurricane Katrina, is located in New Orleans.
Built for the 2008 Summer Olympics, this Beijing stadium is affectionately called the 'Bird's Nest'.
This innovative sports complex in Qatar, for the 2022 FIFA World Cup, includes a stadium that can be completely dismantled.
This planet, known for its prominent rings, was first closely observed by the Pioneer 11 mission in 1979.
In 1969, the Apollo 11 mission landed the first humans on this celestial body.
Like handing off a football, the rover Curiosity was transferred from its traveling spacecraft to explore this red planet in 2012.
Much like a baseball pitcher aiming for an accurate throw, Voyager 2 performed a precise flyby of this ice giant in 1986.
This spacecraft, named after a famous scientist, delivered a Hail Mary discovery of Jupiter's moons during its mission from 1989 to 2003.

final.clue: This athlete, known for winning gold in track & field at four consecutive Olympics, held the 400m relay world record for 36 years with his team.
